Now your bodies are smooth and hard, sculpted action figures expertly crafted down to the finest detail. Or would that be ‘in’action figures? You’re both unable to move, of course. Unable to speak. Unable to complain as you’re bundled up into a nice little box and delivered to a curio shop that seems to exist outside of time and space. You’re not the only items on display here - the place is full of various knick-knacks and antiques. On one wall, a giant grandmother clock. Hanging from the ceiling, model airplanes suspended on strings. In the center of the floor, a marble birdbath. And yet, upon closer inspection, everything within the room has a macabre secret to it - because every single one hides the form of a helpless woman, trapped or transformed by the fae’s wicked magic. Behind the glass of the clock, a tsunojian is shackled in place, the pendulum tick-tocking between her two heaving breasts. And within the seats of the airplanes are tiny, glossy pilots, kemomi women shrunken and transformed to forever operate the controls. And the basin of the birdbath, of course, is clutched between the fingers of a petrified elvaan, the placid smile etched onto her face belying the terror she must have felt in the moment her fate was sealed. As for the two of you, you’re placed at the corner of the reception desk at the front of the store. Though the place rarely seems to get any customers. Despite its appearance, this is not a place of business but a prison, housing the helpless souls of all the women the fae has decided to collect. You and Revissa are two among many, doomed to maintain the same pose and glassy-eyed expressions for the rest of your days. (if: $candy is false)[[[Stand around->FD04X]]] (if: $candy is true)[[[Stand around->FD04Y]]] ] The life of a collectable figurine is not particularly eventful. You stand around, you gleam in the light, and you occasionally spark a conversation between one of the rare visitors and your owner. The fae woman seems to regret the fact that she didn’t collect the full set when she had the chance, that only you were foolish enough to stumble into her clutches. It’s both a relief, knowing that your friends escaped the same fate, but also a source of regret. You’ll probably never see any of them again, after all. Eventually, the fae woman tires of you, and she allows one of her visitors to take you home. But to your new owner, you and Revissa have even less emotional significance than you did for the original woman who caught you. And so you end up changing hands many times over the years. Sometimes you’re loved and cherished, kept clean and dust-free in a place of prominence, and other times you’re shoved in a corner, lost in a back room, or forgotten entirely. The one thing you never are is freed. And you never will be. They say diamonds are forever - but apparently glossy statuettes are as well. Next time, maybe you’ll be more careful about accepting help from a fae. GAME OVER [[Start Over->A0X]]The life of a collectable figurine is not particularly eventful. You stand around, you gleam in the light, and you occasionally spark a conversation between one of the rare visitors and your owner. The fae woman seems to regret the fact that she didn’t collect the full set when she had the chance, that only you were foolish enough to stumble into her clutches. It’s both a relief, knowing that your friends escaped the same fate, but also a source of regret. You’ll probably never see any of them again, after all. Eventually, the fae woman tires of you, and she allows one of her visitors to take you home. But to your new owner, you and Revissa have even less emotional significance than you did for the original woman who caught you. And so you end up changing hands many times over the years. Sometimes you’re loved and cherished, kept clean and dust-free in a place of prominence, and other times you’re shoved in a corner, lost in a back room, or forgotten entirely. It’s not until many years later that a retired Star Scout happens to be browsing an estate sale and notices that a pair of glossy figures are somehow transmitting signals corresponding to an old distress frequency. She purchases the items and manages to get the two of you restored - though it’s been hundreds of years since you were first transformed. And so you find yourself stepping into a galaxy that has changed immensely since you were last a part of it. An exciting new adventure, to be sure, but also rather outside the scope of this one. And, of course, it goes without saying, but you failed the mission you were initially hired to complete. GAME OVER [[Start over->A0X]]“Well, if you enjoyed the show, maybe you can give us something in return?” you ask to the tree. “We’re… uh, kind of lost. Do you know the way to this spot on the map?” You bring up the holo-image from your comm device, pointing at the location where you need to deposit the data collection device. “Oh-ho… yes, I could show you the way…” says the tree. “No trouble at all. A fair trade for revitalizing these old roots of mine with your show.” Well, at least something good has come from your mistake earlier with the pollen. You’re about to agree to the trade, but then you get a soft elbow to the side from your wife. With a sigh, you turn to her to see what the issue is. “Something seems wrong…” Revissa says, looking towards you but with eyes darting suspiciously towards the tree. “Weren’t *you* the one who wanted to ask the plants for help?” “Yes… but… ugh, I don’t know. Something just seems wrong to me. I can’t put my finger on it, but I’m getting bad vibes from this whole thing.” Well, bad vibes or no, you still have a mission to do. And after losing several hours to aimless wandering and intense lovemaking, you really should be getting back to it. [[Accept the tree’s guidance->FD05B]] [[Interrogate the tree further->FD05C]] On the one hand, you trust Revissa’s instincts implicitly. If she thinks there’s something fishy here, she’s probably right. But on the other hand, you can’t just turn down the opportunity to get things back on track. Vhaja is counting on you to install these data devices. “Alright… please show us the way,” you ask to the tree. Revissa gives you a disapproving look. You shrug your shoulders apologetically. “Very well…” says the tree, in its creaking, wooden voice. “All you need do is follow the sound of my voice. This portion of the forest can be quite confusing. Your senses cannot always be relied upon. But my voice will ring true, and serve as a beacon.” So there *was* something unnatural about the forest! No wonder you were getting lost. You puff out your chest proudly. If you hadn’t triggered that pollen, the two of you wouldn’t have gotten frisky, and the tree wouldn’t have been there to get you out of this mess. Sometimes the correct choice is to make a bunch of mistakes and get lucky right at the end. Revissa rolls her eyes at you, but you maintain a bounce in your step as you head out into the woods once again. As promised, the helpful tree guides you along the path, helping you overcome the otherwise distracting and disorienting twists and turns of this portion of the forest. And eventually, you get far enough away from whatever the disturbance was that the map on your comm device seems to be working again, allowing you to navigate the rest of the way with your own skills. Before long, you find yourself entering the very deepest part of the woods, a short distance from your destination. (set: $treetalk to true) [[Head inside->FE01]] You haven’t gotten as far as you have in life without trusting in Revissa’s instincts. The mission is obviously important, but *because* it’s important you need to avoid walking yourself into any traps that might trip you up. “Look,” you say to the tree. “I get you’re offering to help, but you’ve gotta see this from our perspective. We’re in unfamiliar territory, and we’ve only just met you. What proof do we have that you’re not, say, just going to lead us right into the grasp of a sexy spider-babe who’ll web us up and carry us away to her love-making nook?” Revissa gives you the stink-eye. You give her a shrug back. Look, you’re still a bit horny, so you can’t be blamed if your thoughts are leaning towards the fetishistic. A low, raspy, grating laugh creaks out from the tree’s ‘mouth’. It’s the sound of wood on wood, a disorienting scraping noise that doesn’t sound the least bit mirthful. “You haven’t been reading ahead, have you?” says the tree. “Picking the obvious Bad End path to get your jollies on before doubling back to try and actually win?” You raise your eyebrow in confusion. You’re not really sure what the tree is saying… but also it almost feels like it's talking to someone else other than you. But who could that be? It’s not like there’s anyone here but yourself and Revissa. But as you spare your wife a glance, you notice she has become even more tense than earlier. She narrows her eyes as she looks at the face etched into the wood in front of you. “We… are not talking to a tree,” she eventually says. “It is… some kind of fey spirit, I have to assume. A trickster, playing a bit of a joke. Making us think it’s a tree as a jape.” Now the caution in her posture makes sense. You haven’t really had much dealing with the fair folk - not exactly your department. Vhaja has before, you know, together with an unlikely companion she had made, the half-fey daughter of the Winter Queen. And you’re pretty sure Revissa has spoken about making deals with fairykind during her days in the Bolg Resistance. But you’ve been fortunate enough to avoid that realm up until now, though even you know that fae are fickle, capricious, and potentially very dangerous “How delightfully droll,” comes a voice. It’s warm and soft and playful, the polar opposite of the sounds that had been emanating from the ‘mouth’ of the tree-face. “Figured it out so soon, did you?” Suddenly, there is a rush of sound, like sparkling firecrackers popping all around you, then a flash of motion as the leaves behind Revissa’s feet swirl in a multi-colored vortex. You back away instinctively, reaching towards your sword, watching as a figure emerges from the storm and claps its hands. A figure that… is oddly familiar. (link:"Behold My Magnifence, $yourname")[(show:?drink1)] |drink1)[<img src="images/F16_FaeThrone_by_Izra.jpg" style="max-width: 100%;">(css: "font-size: 60%")[Art by Izra(click-replace: "Art by Izra")[https://twitter.com/IZRART https://picarto.tv/IZRA]] (set: $picF16 to true) You recognize the gorgeous woman standing in front of you now. In fact, you were just thinking about her. Skadi, the Winter Witch, the half-fae princess that Vhaja sometimes works with. But… that’s impossible, isn’t it? “The form she is showing is not her true one!” Revissa warns. “She… must be gazing into our memories to construct an image for herself.” The woman who is not Skadi smiles and runs a finger playfully along Revissa’s arm. “And why would you say something like that, my little dear? Or should I say deer? Ho, how clever I can be!” “Because… to me, you look like Un-Rama, the great Guardian Moth, and I know you are not her.” The fey entity throws up her arms. “Guilty as charged! But what’s a little illusion between friends, no? Because… we *are* friends… right?” “That remains to be seen,” Revissa murmurs. “Well, for your sake I hope we are friends. Because you two are lost, and I know the way home.” Suddenly, things start to make sense. Hah! So it wasn’t that you were reading the map poorly. It’s that a trickster spirit was manipulating the terrain around you to make sure you ended up losing your way. There is a pop and not-Skadi is behind you, gently stroking the fluff inside your left ear. “No, my lost little doggie, you got yourself lost all on your own. Though once you *were* lost… I might have bent things around a bit to make sure you stayed that way.” “Why?!” Revissa demands. “Because that way, I can make sure you play my game!” You feel a shiver run down your spine… despite the warm (and not entirely unwelcome) presence of not-Skadi’s bosom compressed against your back. It seems like things have just become very… interesting. [[Find out exactly how interesting->FD05D]] ] “What kind of game?” you ask suspiciously. Revissa kicks you in the shin. “No, don’t even think about playing along. Don’t interact, don’t entertain. Never indulge the whims of a fae, or they’ll just take it as an invitation to keep on bothering you.” “But don’t you worship Un-Rama?” you ask. “She’s a fae spirit.” “She’s different! Un-Rama is a guardian and protector. But this woman… is a trickster. I can tell just by looking at her. She wants nothing more than to lead us into a trap for her own entertainment.” “You wound me!” not-Skadi says, miming being shot through the heart and falling backwards. “And if I wasn’t in such a good mood after watching you two have sex, I’d probably turn you into a frog or something. Which I *could* do, you know. You wouldn’t have any defense against it. Like it or not, I’m much more powerful than either of you, so really it’s in your best interest to entertain me.” You step forward. “Alright… let’s say I did want to entertain you. What’s so special about us that someone as powerful as you has taken an interest?” “Oh, it’s not the *us* so much as the *you*, my darling wolfie. Or actually, your crew. The Rabbit’s Foot Guild! Erm, sorry, wrong universe. The Rabbit’s Foot *Company*, as your merry little band of mercs is called. Right? You’re kind of a big deal. Some might say the biggest deal in this universe.” Okay, now you know she’s pulling your leg. “Big deal? I mean, sure, we had some adventures. Maybe even helped save the galaxy once or twice. But we’re still less famous than the knock-off cartoon series Icewing made based on us” The fae woman giggles. “Ooh, I love you throwing in a reference to the campaign that casual readers wouldn’t recognize. But no, I don’t mean *in-universe* fame, I mean at the meta level. The four of you are probably the most famous characters from this neck of the woods - other than the Demon Queen, I guess.” “By the four of us… you mean me, Krysta, Vhaja, and Lumina?” She claps her hands. “Exactly! Not gonna lie, I’m kind of disappointed you partnered up with the wifey here for the adventure - I prefer classic foursome perils, myself. Which is why, to be perfectly honest, I don’t care for the deer girl - other than as a supporting character in your life. So she really shouldn’t get a say in what happens next in our little tete-a-tete.” Your head is spinning trying to wrap your mind around all of this, but there’s one thing you know for certain. Despite the occasional butting of heads, you love Revissa with all your heart. So you’re not going to just let her be sidelined in this discussion. Instead you’re going to– The fae woman snaps her fingers… and then Revissa is gone. Not teleported, not carried away. Like the frame containing her in the film reel was severed completely. “I’m serious about this,” the woman says, pressing herself up against you. “You’re the main character here, not her. That’s why all the big important, plot-branching decisions always hinge on *your* choices. I mean, seriously, have you noticed that some of the artwork is using older versions of her design? Big pointy ears, no horns, that kind of stuff? What shamelessly lazy production values. Just commission new art if she’s so important, right?” You’re not sure if you want to feel terrified or furious at this woman. Or, to be fair, aroused. She is still incredibly attractive, and her chest is nicely squishing itself against your arm. But whatever she is, it is abundantly clear that she is far too powerful to confront directly. And that you very well might need to play her game if you ever want to see your wife again. (set: $faecycle to 0) [[Play along->FD05E]] [[Run away->FD05DA]] [[Fight her->FD05DB]] [[Seduce her->FD05DC]] (if: $faecycle >5)[You’re not really sure what’s happened. Everything had become a blur, and you felt like you were repeating yourself over and over again, trapped in a never-ending loop. Your head is spinning as you finally bring yourself out of your funk, looking up with bleary eyes towards the fae woman.](else: )[You sigh in defeat. Try as you might, you can’t think of any way to escape this woman’s influence. So as much as it pains you to admit it, your only option is to play along with her game.] “Fine… I guess I have no choice,” you say. “I’ll play your damn game. So what is it you want me to do?” The fae woman throws her hands up into the air theatrically. “Oh, I thought you’d never ask!” She snaps her fingers, and a structure appears with a pop in the center of the clearing you’ve been standing in. It’s some kind of brightly colored, open-air tent, circular in construction with strangely shaped seats arranged around its circumference. You narrow your eyes. “What is this?” “Our game, silly!” You shake your head. “Before we play any games, I want you to tell me what you did with Revissa.” “Oh, but that’s just the thing - she’s already here!” Her eyes dart towards the tent-like structure. You follow where they are looking, and, after a moment of shocked revelation, have to stifle a gasp. (link:"I think she looks cute like this. Don't you, $yourname?")[(show:?drink1)] |drink1)[<img src="images/F18_RevissaGoRound_by_Dreamons.jpg" style="max-width: 100%;">(css: "font-size: 60%")[Art by Dreamons(click-replace: "Art by Dreamons")[https://www.deviantart.com/dreamons2]] (set: $picF18 to true) What you thought was a tent was actually an old-timey mechanized merry-go-round, the kind you might find at a carnival, or at Floofyland™. But the seats on the ride are all hybridized female figures, half animal, half person. Revissa, of course, often takes the form of what you lovingly call a deer-taur, a quadrupedal cervid with a humanoid torso. And she’s taking that form now, but her body is stiff and glossy, with a pole through her midsection and a saddle painted onto her back. “Wh… what the hell have you done to her!” you yell, as your arm subconsciously reaches for the sword on your back. The fae woman chuckles. "I’ve done to her something I could just as easily could do to you, if I wanted to. And something I *will* do if your hand gets any closer to that sword.” She vanishes in a puff of smoke, then reappears right beside you, pressing her bosom against your side. “Need I remind you, I control her fate. She’s become a glossy little prop, a background element of your story. And she’ll stay that way unless you agree to play along.” Her voice has become frighteningly ominous, and you can’t help but shiver with anxiety. “Okay… fine. It’s not like I have a choice. I’ll play whatever game you have in mind. But if’s a game, there *are* rules, right? Rules that you’ll follow?” “Of course! I am a woman of my word, after all. The rules are even quite simple. We’re going to have a race! You and I choose a mount, and whichever one makes three laps around the merry-go-round first is the winner!” You narrow your eyes. “And if I win, you’ll restore Revissa and let us go?” “If you win you get a prize,” she says. “Getting your wife back can be that prize, if you wish.” This is why Revissa says not to trust the fae. You can *feel* the way she is arranging her words, deliberately leaving wiggle room in any condition she agrees to. If you were a smarter woman, you would try to parse where in her statement she might trip you up. But you’re no lawyer, and you were never particularly good at riddles. So all you can do is play along and hope your instincts kick in before you fall into one of her semantic traps. But there is at least one thing you can confirm. “Alright… so obviously I’m going to pick Revissa. But I’ll only agree if you play fair. Whichever mount you choose as your racer has to go at the same speed as Revissa does.” “Done!” the fae says quickly. *Too* quickly. If she’s planning on cheating, clearly altering the speed of the racers isn’t how she’s going to do it. But you can’t think of any more obvious hacks she could use. With no other ideas left, you trundle off to the merry-go-round and plop your butt down on Revissa’s smooth, glossy backside - something that requires a bit of maneuvering, given her long hair braid is stiffly protruding behind her, poking into your arm as you try to settle in. Clearly this ride wasn’t built for comfort. You wonder idly if she’s still conscious, if behind that placid smile frozen on her face she’s screaming at you to back out, or trying to tell you about the obvious trick you’re walking right into. But if there are any words on her mind, they don’t escape her lips. All you can do is wrap your arms around her smooth shoulders and hold on, as the ride whirs to life. [[Off to the races->FD06B]] ] (if: $faecycle > 30)[(prepend: ?sidebar)[$faecycle]] (if: $faecycle is 100)[(link: "This is absurd. You just don’t give up. This goes beyond persistence. You’re just a glutton for punishment, I guess. Alright then, at this point, I’m just going to have to take you out of the story entirely. Click this text.")[(go-to: "VOID1")]](else: )[(set: $faecycle to it + 1) You’re not going to play this woman’s game. But you know you can’t beat her in a fight, either. Which means the best option is a tactical retreat. You peel away from her and dash into the trees, running as fast as your legs can carry you. And yet, after a minute of effort, the path opens up right back into the clearing you had just fled from. (if: $faecycle is 5)["This is getting old!” the fae woman says, sitting herself down on a nearby tree stump. “You’re just repeating yourself now. Please just pick the first option so we can get on with things.”](else-if: $faecycle is 10)["Really? Ten times now? At this point I have to guess that you’re just wasting your time, trying to see if anything else will change. Well, fine. Do it ten more times and I’ll give you another option.”](else-if: $faecycle is 20)["Wow, you really did it! Okay, there you go, another option, like I promised. Go on, click it. You know you want to!"](else-if: $faecycle > 30)[“Seriously? You’re still here? My secret option wasn’t good enough for you? Well I’m not giving you any more rewards for wasting my time. Have fun, loser!](else: )[“All-powerful fae, remember?” not-Skadi says, finishing the hand motion for the spell that pulled you back here. “Now can we just get on with things?”] (if: $faecycle is > 30)[](else: )[[[Play along->FD05E]]] [[Fight her->FD05DB]] [[Seduce her->FD05DC]] (if: $faecycle is > 30)[](else-if: $faecycle >= 20)[[[Become a collectable action figure->FD05F]]] ] (if: $faecycle > 30)[(prepend: ?sidebar)[$faecycle]] (if: $faecycle is 100)[(link: "This is absurd. It’s a long shot, but maybe if you can get in a lucky hit you might be able to disorient her. Reaching to your belt, you pull out your trusty blaster pistol and take aim, trying to shoot down the branch above the fae woman’s head. However, when the energy bolt leaves the muzzle of your gun, it somehow arcs around and reverses course, dislodging a branch over your *own* head. It strikes your noggin with a painful bump, making you dizzy for a moment.
